channel.title: Causal Inference on Elise Gould: PhD Research Notebook
channel.description: Recent content in Causal Inference on Elise Gould: PhD Research Notebook

item.title: Seaman & Weber (2015) Undisclosed Flexibility in Computing and Reporting Structural Equation Models in Communication Science.
item.author: elise.gould@unimelb.edu.au (Elise Gould)
item.description: Summary This paper is a systematic review (or ‘methodological review’ in their tersm) of both QRPs and bad modelling practice in structural equation modelling within the field of communication. They don’t use the term ‘Questionable Research Practices’, however, they do explicitly look at practices falling under the QRP banner, including cherry-picking, HARKing, and researcher degrees of freedom. Importantly, this paper is really useful to me because they examine these questionable research practices in a modelling framework outside of the non-hypothetico-deductive scientific model.

item.title: Law et al. (2017) Biol Con
item.author: elise.gould@unimelb.edu.au (Elise Gould)
item.description: Law, E. A., Ferraro, P. J., Arcese, P., Bryan, B. A., Davis, K., Gordon, A., Holden, M. H., Iacona, G., Martinez, R. M., McAlpine, C. A., Rhodes, J. R., Sze, J. S., Wilson, K. A. (2017) Projecting the performance of conservation interventions. BIOC doi: 10.1016/j.biocon.2017.08.029. Problem: Projecting the performance of conservation interventions Successful decision-making for environmental management requires reliable evidence for both the performance and efficacy of proposed conservation actions.
